title: Profile
text:
Student, Information and Communications Technology
Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT)
Temasek Polytechnic alumni with an interest in data, technology, and applied learning.
Focused on using data and simple tools to improve real‑world processes.
You can find more of my work here:
 





I am currently studying at SIT, after completing my diploma at Temasek Polytechnic.
My interests are in data analytics, simple automation, and applying technology to areas like supply chain and inventory management.




Singapore Institute of Technology – ICT student

Temasek Polytechnic – Diploma related to supply chain / logistics





Final Year Project (Temasek Polytechnic) – Worked in a team of four to explore ways to improve inventory management and overall supply chain efficiency.

Stock analysis dashboard – Built a dashboard that visualises stock performance and trading decisions using quantitative data.





Data visualisation and dashboards

Programming with Python

title: FYP Project
text:
I was a Temasek Polytechnic alumni and my Final Year Project focused on improving inventory management and overall supply chain efficiency.
Together with my group mates, we looked for practical ways to reduce delays, avoid stockouts, and make day‑to‑day operations smoother for businesses.

Time period: Aug 2022 – Mar 2023

Team: Group of 4

Role: Data gathering, analysis, and helping to design the proposed workflow





Data collection and research
We reviewed articles and case studies on supply chain optimisation and spoke with staff to understand pain points such as inaccurate stock levels and manual tracking.
Exploring solutions and challenges
We compared different ideas (better barcode usage, clearer reorder rules, simple tracking tools) while considering cost, training, and how easily they could fit into existing processes.
Showcase room concept
To present our ideas, we designed a small “template showcase room” layout that demonstrated how the proposed solutions might look in a real storeroom or warehouse, using example shelves, labels, and simple process diagrams.






Even small changes in workflow and visibility can make a big difference to inventory accuracy.

Technical solutions only work if they match how people actually work on the ground, so communication with end‑users is important.

This page shares one visualization work that my group and I created during our student life.
The example uses a dashboard to visualise quantitative stock data with multiple graphs.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this website, I used GenAI tools such as Perplexity to guide me through the Quarto setup and to fix issues with the navbar, YAML, and images. They helped me find the right syntax more quickly and suggested clearer ways to structure each page.

title: Data Visualization
text:
This page presents one quantitative data visualization I created during my studies.


You can view the full code for this visualization on my GitHub repository.
 My group and I created a stock visualization web app:

The top panel tracks my total number of trades, realised profit and loss, and win rate over the semester.
The line charts show daily price movements and indicators for different stocks.
The bottom panel visualizes my buy and sell points, which helped me reflect on my trading decisions.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this website, I used GenAI tools such as Perplexity to guide me through the Quarto setup and to fix issues with the navbar, YAML, and images. They helped me find the right syntax more quickly and suggested clearer ways to structure each page.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
What helped me
The main benefit was saving time. Instead of reading long documentation, I could ask specific questions and get targeted answers, then adapt them to my own project. This also helped me spot mistakes I might have missed on my own.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
What I learned
At the same time, I realised I still had to understand what I was doing. When something did not work, I had to check the code, compare it with my files, and make my own decisions. Going forward, I expect to use GenAI in a similar way: as a quick helper for ideas and troubleshooting, while I remain responsible for the final work and my own understanding.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Stockie – Stock Analysis Dashboard
You can view the full code for this visualization on our
GitHub repository.

title: Data Visualization
text:
What is visualised

The summary section at the top shows numeric indicators such as number of trades, realised profit or loss, and win rate for the period.

The time‑series charts display stock prices, indicators, and trading volume over time, so each point on the graph represents a specific numerical value on a given date.

The bottom chart marks our buy and sell points, allowing us to see exactly where trades happened along the price curve.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Story and rationale
Our group created this dashboard to review our trading behaviour and understand how our decisions affected performance.
We chose a line‑based time‑series layout because it clearly shows trends and volatility over time, which is important for stock data.
Placing summary statistics above and detailed graphs below lets us quickly check overall results first, then drill down into individual trades to see whether our entries and exits were well‑timed or need improvement.

title: Hobbies
text:
Exercising is my number one hobby. I am part of the calisthenics club at my school and train regularly through running, cycling, swimming, gym work, and everything in between.
I love exercising because it gives me a sense of purpose and keeps me healthy and fit. One of my goals is to master cool calisthenics moves like the muscle up, which requires months of consistent training and discipline.
Here’s a quick clip of me training: 
What I do: - Train at the gym 4-5 times a week, focusing on strength and calisthenics progression - Run and cycle on weekends for cardio and outdoor fitness - Swim occasionally to mix up my routine and build endurance - Track my progress and set new fitness goals regularly




I am passionate about the stock market and day trading. I follow market trends daily, research companies, and actively trade to improve my skills and understanding of how the market works.
Because of this interest, I built a coding project to track my trading analytics. The dashboard shows metrics like profitability by hour, PnL (profit and loss), win rate, and other key statistics so I can review my trading decisions and improve over time.
What I do: - Trade stocks daily and review my decisions - Research companies and market trends - Maintain a trading journal and analyse my performance - Build tools to visualise and track trading metrics




Both hobbies teach me discipline and consistency. Fitness reminds me that small daily efforts add up to big results, and trading teaches me that patience and learning from mistakes are just as important as getting wins.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Context
Our group created this dashboard to analyse stock trends. We chose a line‑based time‑series layout because it clearly shows trends and volatility over time, which is important for stock data.
Placing summary statistics above and detailed graphs below lets us quickly check overall results first, then drill down into individual trades to see whether our entries and exits were well‑timed or need improvement.

title: Data Visualization
text:
How we built it
The dashboard uses Python and Plotly for interactive charts. Here’s a sample:
import plotly.graph_objects as go

# Create candlestick chart
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Candlestick(
    x=df['Date'],
    open=df['Open'],
    high=df['High'],
    low=df['Low'],
    close=df['Close']
)])
fig.show()
